article: How to Identify a Refurbished iPhone
intro: This wikiHow teaches you how to tell whether or not your iPhone has been refurbished. iPhones are typically considered "refurbished" when they have been repaired and re-sold by Apple or a third-party vendor after a hardware issue was found in the original phone.

steps.title: See if your iPhone is refurbished.
steps.subtitle: The first letter in the model name will tell you your iPhone's status:
sub-points: If the first letter is "M" or "P", your phone is an original (retail) model.
If the first letter is "N", your phone was refurbished by Apple.
If the first letter is "F", your phone was refurbished by a carrier or a third-party vendor.

steps.title: See if your iPhone is refurbished.
steps.subtitle: The first letter in the model name will tell you your iPhone's status:
sub-points: If the first letter is "M" or "P", your phone is an original (retail) model.
If the first letter is "N", your phone was refurbished by Apple.
If the first letter is "F", your phone was refurbished by a carrier or a third-party vendor.

steps.title: See if your iPhone is refurbished.
steps.subtitle: The first letter in the model name will tell you your iPhone's status:
sub-points: If the first letter is "M" or "P", your phone is an original (retail) model.
If the first letter is "N", your phone was refurbished by Apple.
If the first letter is "F", your phone was refurbished by a carrier or a third-party vendor.

steps.title: Review your iPhone's status.
steps.subtitle: If the phone is brand-new, you'll see something like "This phone has not been activated" at the top of the page.
sub-points: If you verify that the iPhone has been activated and the seller is attempting to sell it as a new phone, consider buying from a different source.
